title: 108_s1677
content: The "Community College Partnership Act of 2003" aims to enhance student retention, transfer opportunities to 4-year institutions, and prepare students for high-demand occupations. The "Community College Partnership Act of 2003" defines a community or technical college as an institution of higher education that admits students beyond compulsory school age, does not primarily offer baccalaureate degrees, and provides a program of at least 2 years for credit towards a baccalaureate degree. A community or technical college must offer a 2-year program in engineering, mathematics, or the physical or biological sciences, designed for technician or semiprofessional work in related fields. The institution must be accredited by a recognized regional accrediting agency. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of partnerships between statewide governance boards for community or technical colleges and institutions offering baccalaureate degrees. This can be achieved through a statewide governance board, a partnership between different governance boards, or a partnership between colleges and universities. The Secretary shall award grants to eligible entities for education programs offering baccalaureate or postbaccalaureate degrees. Priority will be given to entities meeting specified criteria. Grants awarded under this chapter prioritize entities addressing college retention and transfer issues. The grants last 5 or 6 years and support policies to help community college students earn baccalaureate degrees. Services for participating students are also funded. The program provides support services like tutoring, mentoring, counseling, and academic enhancements at community colleges to improve program quality, connect to high-demand occupations, and increase student participation in dual degree programs. It also aims to identify barriers hindering student transfers. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations necessary to carry out the program, focusing on improving program quality, connecting to high-demand occupations, increasing student participation in dual degree programs, and identifying barriers hindering student transfers. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2004 and the following three years is set at $70,000,000 to carry out the program outlined in the chapter.
